news_summary: Offshore wind power played a crucial role in providing reliable and clean energy during the East Coast’s severe cold weather.
news_summary_fr: L'énergie éolienne offshore a joué un rôle crucial dans la fourniture d'une énergie fiable et propre pendant la vague de froid qui a frappé la côte Est.

articles.title: Offshore wind showed up big during the East Coast’s brutal cold
articles.content:
This story was originally published by Canary Media and is reproduced here as part of the Climate Desk collaboration.

Bone-chilling cold and Arctic winds gripped the northeastern U.S. over the past few weeks, straining electricity systems and raising power prices as people cranked up their heat. Now, as the region finally starts to thaw, early data shows how America’s offshore wind farms helped keep electricity flowing during the extreme-weather stretch.

The results demonstrate the bitter irony of the Trump administration’s ongoing — and potentially unlawful — battle against U.S. offshore wind development. Federal officials are calling for additional fossil fuel power to prevent future winter blackouts, all while trying to block the build-out of offshore wind, one of the most valuable resources for cold-climate coastal states.

“Performance data is showing in real time that offshore wind delivers reliable power when the grid needs it the most … at the scale this region and our country need,” said Liz Burdock, president and CEO of Oceantic Network, which advocates for marine renewable energy sectors.

Burdock was speaking on Tuesday in New York City at the group’s annual International Partnering Forum, where hundreds of offshore wind developers, policy experts, and labor leaders gathered to regroup following President Donald Trump’s yearlong attacks on five in-progress offshore wind farms.

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

For years, independent energy experts have forecast that offshore wind could deliver substantial amounts of power to densely-populated, land-constrained communities along America’s east coast — particularly during winter cold spells, when demand for fossil gas exceeds supply. And grid operators in the region have been banking on offshore wind capacity to come online to meet the rising electricity needs of data centers and electrified homes and vehicles.

The data from January shows that the nation’s two operating utility-scale offshore wind farms — South Fork Wind and Vineyard Wind — performed as well as gas-fired power plants and better than coal-fired facilities, including during last month’s Winter Storm Fern, experts said at the event.

The 132-megawatt South Fork Wind farm, which delivers power to Long Island, New York, had a ​“capacity factor” of 52 percent last month. The metric reflects how much electricity the project actually generated compared with the maximum amount it could generate in a given period. That puts South Fork Wind on par with New York state’s most efficient gas plants.

“The wind capacity in the Northeast is absolutely amazing, particularly over the winter,” said Mikkel Mæhlisen, vice president of the Americas Generation division for Ørsted, which jointly owns South Fork Wind with Skyborn Renewables.

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

The 12-turbine project became America’s first utility-scale offshore wind farm in 2024, when it started providing power to some 70,000 homes. Last winter, it was also a beacon of reliability, notching a 54 percent capacity factor between December 2024 and March 2025.

Vineyard Wind, meanwhile, can already produce as much as 600 MW of clean electricity off the coast of Massachusetts. The project, which is 95 percent complete, is one of the five offshore wind farms that were forced to halt construction late last year in response to Trump’s stop-work orders, which cited ambiguous ​“national security” concerns. Federal judges have allowed all five projects to proceed as the developers’ complaints move through the legal system.

However, Interior Secretary Doug Burgum says the Trump administration plans to appeal those court rulings, Bloomberg reported on Wednesday.

During Winter Storm Fern, Vineyard Wind had a 75 percent capacity factor, Burdock said. Once fully operational, the project will deliver power at a price of $84.23 per megawatt-hour to the New England grid. That’s markedly less than spot wholesale prices during the storm, which spiked to over $870 per MWh on January 25.

Soaring gas prices and limited supplies pushed utilities in New England to fire up oil-burning power plants in order to avert blackouts, assets that are typically too expensive to justify running. The result will be even higher bills for the region’s residents, who have historically faced some of the highest energy costs in the nation — in part because New England lacks recoverable resources like oil and gas, said Katie Dykes, commissioner of Connecticut’s Department of Energy and Environmental Protection.

Having a more diverse energy mix would help states reduce the reliance on firm, dispatchable, but also costly and dirty power plants during such challenging periods.

“Variable resources like wind and solar, when they’re operating during these cold weather periods, they’re actually helping to keep a lid on prices,” Dykes said during a panel. ​“It means we can reduce the runtimes of those more expensive oil units. It also means that we can preserve the runtime of those [fossil] resources that are relying on stored fuel.”

Proponents of America’s nascent offshore wind industry said they’re hopeful the five in-progress projects will be completed as planned. In New York, Ørsted’s Sunrise Wind and Equinor’s Empire Wind would together provide 1.7 gigawatts of new capacity — enough to meet more than 10 percent of the electricity needs in New York City and Long Island.

“The last few weeks have been extremely stressful,” Gary Stephenson, a senior vice president for the Long Island Power Authority, said about the region’s cold snap. The municipal utility, which serves 1.2 million customers, purchases power from South Fork Wind and will connect its grid to Sunrise Wind, which is expected to start operating in 2027.

“I really wish we had that Sunrise facility online. That would have taken so much pressure off the natural gas system,” Stephenson said at the event. ​“So we’re looking forward to that [coming online] towards the end of next year.”

articles.personality_title: Offshore wind farms helped power the East Coast through a harsh winter cold
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The northeastern United States faced extremely cold weather recently, causing high demand for electricity as people used more heating. This put a lot of pressure on the power system and made energy prices rise.

**What happened** – During this cold spell, two offshore wind farms, South Fork Wind near New York and Vineyard Wind near Massachusetts, provided a steady and reliable supply of electricity. These wind farms worked as well as or better than some gas and coal power plants, even during the severe Winter Storm Fern in January 2025.

**Impact** – This shows offshore wind energy can be a strong and dependable source of power in cold weather, which is important because it helps avoid blackouts and reduces reliance on expensive, polluting fuels like oil and gas. For example, South Fork Wind powered about 70,000 homes and reached a capacity factor similar to the best gas plants. Vineyard Wind performed even better during the storm and will soon produce clean electricity at much lower costs than emergency fossil fuel plants.

**What's next step** – Five more offshore wind projects are underway but faced delays due to political challenges. However, courts have allowed work to continue, and developers hope to complete these farms soon. When finished, projects like Sunrise Wind and Empire Wind will provide large amounts of clean energy to areas like New York City, helping to lower pressure on gas systems during future cold spells.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Offshore wind farms proved their value by delivering reliable, affordable electricity during a severe winter, showing their important role in the region’s energy future.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les éoliennes en mer ont alimenté la côte Est pendant un hiver rigoureux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le nord-est des États-Unis a connu récemment un froid glacial, ce qui a fortement augmenté la demande d’électricité pour le chauffage. Cela a mis à rude épreuve le réseau électrique et fait grimper les prix de l’énergie.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Pendant cette vague de froid, deux parcs éoliens offshore, South Fork Wind près de New York et Vineyard Wind près du Massachusetts, ont fourni une électricité stable et fiable. Ces parcs ont fonctionné aussi bien, voire mieux, que certaines centrales à gaz et à charbon, même pendant la violente tempête d’hiver Fern en janvier 2025.

**Impact** – Cela montre que l’énergie éolienne en mer peut être une source d’électricité forte et fiable par temps froid, ce qui aide à éviter les coupures de courant et à réduire la dépendance aux combustibles coûteux et polluants comme le pétrole et le gaz. Par exemple, South Fork Wind a alimenté environ 70 000 foyers avec un taux de capacité comparable aux meilleures centrales à gaz. Vineyard Wind a eu une performance encore meilleure pendant la tempête et produira bientôt une électricité propre à un coût bien inférieur à celui des centrales fossiles d’urgence.

**Prochaine étape** – Cinq autres projets éoliens en mer sont en cours mais ont été retardés par des obstacles politiques. Cependant, les tribunaux ont permis la reprise des travaux, et les développeurs espèrent terminer ces parcs rapidement. Une fois terminés, des projets comme Sunrise Wind et Empire Wind fourniront de grandes quantités d’énergie propre à des régions comme New York, réduisant la pression sur les réseaux à gaz lors de futurs épisodes froids.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les parcs éoliens offshore ont prouvé leur utilité en fournissant une électricité fiable et abordable pendant un hiver sévère, montrant leur rôle important dans l’avenir énergétique de la région.
articles.personality_title_es: Los parques eólicos marinos ayudaron a abastecer la costa este durante un invierno muy frío
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El noreste de Estados Unidos enfrentó un frío extremo recientemente, lo que aumentó mucho la demanda de electricidad para calefacción. Esto puso mucha presión en el sistema eléctrico y elevó los precios de la energía.

**Qué pasó** – Durante esta ola de frío, dos parques eólicos marinos, South Fork Wind cerca de Nueva York y Vineyard Wind cerca de Massachusetts, suministraron electricidad constante y confiable. Estos parques funcionaron tan bien o mejor que algunas plantas de gas y carbón, incluso durante la fuerte tormenta invernal Fern en enero de 2025.

**Impacto** – Esto demuestra que la energía eólica marina puede ser una fuente fuerte y confiable de electricidad en clima frío, lo que ayuda a evitar apagones y reduce la dependencia de combustibles caros y contaminantes como el petróleo y el gas. Por ejemplo, South Fork Wind abasteció a unas 70,000 casas con un factor de capacidad similar a las mejores plantas de gas. Vineyard Wind tuvo un mejor desempeño durante la tormenta y pronto producirá electricidad limpia a un costo mucho menor que las plantas fósiles de emergencia.

**Próximo paso** – Hay cinco proyectos eólicos marinos más en proceso, pero enfrentaron retrasos por desafíos políticos. Sin embargo, los tribunales han permitido que continúen las obras, y los desarrolladores esperan terminar estos parques pronto. Cuando estén listos, proyectos como Sunrise Wind y Empire Wind proveerán grandes cantidades de energía limpia a áreas como la ciudad de Nueva York, ayudando a reducir la presión en los sistemas de gas durante futuras olas de frío.

**Frase clave** – Los parques eólicos marinos demostraron su valor al entregar electricidad confiable y asequible durante un invierno severo, mostrando su papel importante en el futuro energético de la región.
articles.image_prompt: A serene coastal seascape at dawn with graceful offshore wind turbines rising from the calm ocean waters, their blades gently turning against a backdrop of softly glowing winter skies, while stylized warm light flows from the turbines toward a nearby silhouette of a peaceful coastal town wrapped in a subtle protective aura, symbolizing reliable clean energy sustaining the community through harsh cold.
